question.name: q1
question.text: Rate the overall performance of this resident.

option.description: Not at PGY-1
Attending (aspirational)

question.name: q2
question.text: Handoffs: Please rate this resident's performance in conducting safe, thorough, efficient handoffs when transitioning care from one provider to another.

option.description: No handoff performed
Handoffs performed at a level appropriate for a PGY-1 resident.
Handoffs performed at a level appropriate for a CA-1 resident.
Handoffs performed at a level appropriate for a CA-2 resident.
Handoffs performed at a level appropriate for a CA-3 resident.
Handoffs performed at a level appropriate for an attending (aspirational).

question.name: q3
question.text: Patient Care: Residents involved in pediatric care should be able to develop an anesthetic plan and be able to deliver it in a safe manner.

option.description: Unable to formulate any anesthetic plan.
Obtains important medical, surgical and family history related to anesthesia.

Formulates basic anesthetic plan for patients undergoing routine pediatric procedures taking into account past medical, surgical and family history (i.e. inguinal hernia repairs, egd/colonoscopies, t/a) Conducts basic anesthetic monitoring routine parameters with close supervision.

Formulates anesthetic plans for patients undergoing subspecialty procedures taking into account past medical, surgical and family history (i.e. vps replacement, craniotomy, abdominal procedures in neonates) Conducts subspecialty anesthetics with indirect supervision.

Formulates and tailors anesthetic plans for patients undergoing emergent complex procedures taking into account past medical, surgical and family history (i.e. neonate with bowel obstruction/perforation, pediatric trauma patient) with minimal supervision. Conducts complex anesthetics with minimal supervision. Supervises junior residents and medical students in the management of complex anesthetics.

Independently formulates and tailors anesthetic plans for patients undergoing simple, moderate and emergent complex procedures taking into account past medical, surgical and family history Conducts complex anesthetics independently.

question.name: q4
question.text: Patient Care: Residents involved in pediatric care should be able assess peri-anesthetic care for related complications and manage them appropriately.

option.description: Unable to identify peri-anesthetic complications.
Identifies peri-anesthetic complications and begins initial management of complications with direct supervision.

Performs perioperative assessment to identify complications related to anesthetic care (i.e. in PACU oversedation and desaturation, lip ulcer post prolonged intubation and taping, ) with direct supervision.

Identifies and manages peri-anesthetic complications related to medically complex and subspecialty pediatric anesthesia (i.e. oversedation in a craniotomy, inadequate volume resuscitation in trauma); requests appropriate consultations with supervision.
Identifies and manages all peri-anesthetic complications with min supervision.
Independently identifies and manages all peri-anesthetic complications.

question.name: q5
question.text: Patient Care: Residents rotating in pediatric anesthesia should be able to deal with critically ill patients in a timely manner.

option.description: Unable to recognize acutely ill patients
Recognizes acutely ill or medically deteriorating pediatric patients. Initiates basic medical care for common acute problems and calls for help appropriately.
Constructs prioritized differential diagnoses and initiates treatment with supervision.

Identifies and manages clinical crises (i.e. hypovolemia in a post tonsillectomy bleeding patient, laryngospasm during induction or post extubation ) with supervision. Requires direct supervision in complex crises (i.e. major trauma or neonatal surgery).

Identifies and manages clinically complex crises (i.e. hemodynamic instability in a pediatric patient with major blood loss, manages anticipated difficult airway or ICU intubation) with minimal supervision. Supervises medical students and assigns tasks to OR staff if needed during a crisis.
Manages complex crises independently. Coordinates medical students, junior residents and OR staff during a crisis.

question.name: q6
question.text: Patient Care: Residents during their pediatric anesthesiology rotations must evaluate and manage the airway in children of various sizes and of various pathologies.

option.description: Unable to recognize airway patency.
Recognizes airway patency. Positions child for proper airway management. Attempts bag mask ventilation with assistance.

Prepares equipment and supplies for pediatric airway management (proper size ETT, stylet, oral airways). Performs basic bag mask ventilation in children with direct supervision. Recognizes need for proper size adjunct devices such as oral and nasal airways. Manages placement of supraglottic device and endotracheal tube in normal airways.

Recognizes potential difficult airway and prepares appropriate equipment and supplies for management of difficult airway. Manages most normal pediatric airways with min guidance. Recognizes difficulty with either airway or equipment and asks for help at appropriate times. Identifies and corrects problems and complications associated with the pediatric airway (hypoxemia, bradycardia, right main stem intubation) with supervision.

Manages most pediatric airway cases including special situations such as craniofacial malformations trauma and tracheostomies. Performs advanced management techniques such as fiberoptic intubation. Identifies and corrects problems and complications associated with the pediatric airway (hypoxemia, bradycardia, right main stem intubation) with min guidance.

Independently assesses and manages the pediatric airway in all clinical situations including children with craniofacial syndromes. Independently supervises and provides consultation to other health care providers regarding airway management.

question.name: q7
question.text: Patient Care: Residents during their pediatric anesthesiology rotations should be able to use routine equipment and be able to troubleshoot them.

option.description: Unable to use routine standard ASA monitoring devices.
Demonstrates the correct use of standard ASA monitoring devices (BP, ECG, pulse oximeter, temperature). Interprets data from standard ASA monitoring including recognition of artifacts.
Performs pre-anesthetic equipment and machine checks. Recognizes and appropriately troubleshoots malfunctions of standard ASA monitors.
Inserts arterial catheters with direct supervision. Recognizes and troubleshoots malfunctions of anesthesia machines and of advanced airway equipment (i.e. fiberoptic scopes, glidescopes).

Inserts arterial catheters with minimal direction. Supervises medical students and/or junior residents in the interpretation of monitoring devices. Recognizes equipment malfunctions and troubleshoots appropriately with minimal supervision.
Independently interprets monitoring data (including arterial line tracing, capnography) and troubleshoots malfunctioning equipment.

question.name: q8
question.text: Interpersonal and Communication Skills: During their pediatric anesthesiology rotation, residents are expected to communicate with children and their families; they have to explain perioperative anesthetic management of children of all ages.

option.description: Unable to communicate with children and families.

Demonstrates empathy for pediatric patients and families. Communicates simple information (such as surgical procedure, npo information) with indirect supervision. Observes and Identifies family conflicts and seeks assistance for resolution.
Explains simple anesthetic plans in a timely fashion. Discusses anesthetic plan with surgical colleagues. Identifies family concerns and questions.

Explains moderate complexity anesthetic plans, procedural risks and benefits and post-operative management and disposition with supervision. Manages any family concerns with supervision. Anticipates blood transfusion needs and discusses with families.

Ensures effective communication among all members of health care team and patients and families with min supervision. Explains complex anesthetic plans (craniotomies, neonatal surgery), procedural risks and benefits (epidurals in younger children) and post-operative management and disposition with min supervision. Manages any family concerns with min supervision. Consults additional resources to assist with perioperative management (pediatric services such as hematology, critical care, social services).

Ensures effective communication among all members of health care team and patients and families. Independently explains anesthetic plan, procedural risks and benefits and post-operative management and disposition. Independently manages any family conflicts. Independently discloses errors and adverse events in conjunction with surgical team and based on hospital’s policies and procedures.

question.name: q9
question.text: Medical Knowledge: Residents should be able to manage simple and complex pediatric patients based on their ABA content knowledge.

option.description: Lacks basic knowledge of common medical and surgical problems
Demonstrates basic knowledge of the pathophysiology of common medical and surgical problems, but needs supervision in applying that knowledge to the pediatric patient.

Demonstrates knowledge of the pathophysiology of common medical and surgical problems and is able to apply that knowledge to the pediatric patient (i.e. respiratory disease-croup/tracheitis, URI, CF, MH, musculoskeletal disease). This resident is able to outline premedication methods in pediatric patients (i.e. oral midazolam, PPI). This resident is also able to discuss inhalational vs intravenous induction in children and their complications.

Knows ASA physical status classification and is able to assign it to the pediatric patient with minimal guidance. Demonstrates knowledge of complex medical problems associated with pediatric anesthesia (i.e. muscular dystrophy and MH, trisomy 21 and airway difficulties).

Demonstrates knowledge of specific disease processes and interactions with pediatric anesthetic management (i.e. neonatal physiology, craniofacial syndromes). Demonstrates pediatric induction, intraoperative management and postoperative pain control in a pediatric patient with minimal direction.

Has the knowledge to function independently as an anesthesiology consultant; this includes knowledge of pathophysiology of disease processes and their anesthetic implications and knowledge of pediatric perioperative anesthetic complications.

question.name: q10
question.text: Professionalism: Residents rotating through Children's Hospital of Wisconsin should be able to complete daily tasks reliably.

option.description: Works alone, does not follow departmental or institutional rules.

Follows basic departmental rules and complies with institutional policies and regulations (i.e. reports airway consults or preoperative evaluation consults to more senior residents, reports nursing staff/colleague concerns to appropriate persons).
Completes routine tasks reliably in straightforward situations with supervision (i.e. preoperative evaluation of pediatric cases and discussion with faculty the night prior to procedure).

Completes tasks reliably in complex clinical situations (i.e. subspecialty cases such as crani) or unfamiliar environment (i.e. Emergency department trauma or ICU intubation or Code call) with minimal supervision.

Completes any work assignments reliably and supports other healthcare members to ensure optimization of pediatric anesthesia care with indirect supervision. Supervises junior residents and medical students on time and task management with minimal supervision.

Leads any pediatric anesthesia team independently. Models responsibility and accountability. Follows all departmental and institutional policies and works with nursing staff, surgical colleagues and other health care professionals for better patient outcome.

question.name: q11
question.text: Professionalism: Residents rotating through Children's Hospital of Wisconsin should be able to work as a team to complete daily tasks.

option.description: Works alone, does not follow departmental or institutional rules.

Follows basic departmental rules and complies with institutional policies and regulations (i.e. reports airway consults or preoperative evaluation consults to more senior residents, reports nursing staff/colleague concerns to appropriate persons).
Acts reliably as a team member. Assists with preparation of cases during the day. Follows direct instructions and completes tasks in a timely fashion (i.e. prepares).

Acts reliably as a team member and serves as a counselor to medical students and junior residents regarding team work and professional behavior (i.e. nursing staff interactions, ICU transfers and hand off reports).
Serves as a team leader with minimal direction and works well with the rest of the pediatric anesthesia team to manage cases and complete all tasks assigned.

Leads any pediatric anesthesia team independently. Models responsibility and accountability. Follows all departmental and institutional policies and works with nursing staff, surgical colleagues and other health care professionals for better patient outcome.

question.name: q12
question.text: Overall assessment for this time period. Based on the resident's current level of training (e.g. CA1, CA2, CA3), I feel that this resident:

option.description: Did not meet expectations
Met expectations with concerns
Met expectations

question.text: Please write any comments, concerns, or recommendations you have for this resident.
